reviewText: My 9 year old daughter cried and laughted and made some profound statements about the value of having parents, good friends, compassion and love. What more can you want from a movie? She thanked me for her Christmas gifts, and understood that there are things more important in life. Maybe next year I can try to gift her only an orange? LOL, that would be great! This movie is a Christmas gem.  Yes it is sad and it is not for younger than 8. (Spoiler:At least two important characters die.) But the "feel good" scenes prevail, and the message is loud and clear. It is similar to the Secret Garden, Little Princess, Anne of GG and other orphan stories. There is nothing scary, just sad.  The ending is satisfying although not expected. I appreciated them not making it all wrapped up with the bow at the end.  Enjoy!!! (not sure boys would care about this one)
summary: Sweet mother-daughter bonding movie (a bit sad at moments)

reviewText: Thanksgiving was supposed to be dominated by Abe Lincoln and 007, however they were trumped by a beautiful  Christmas story on DVD.  Christmas Oranges is a triumph and were this largely a theatrical film, there would be Academy Award nominations in a number of categories.  Leading would be Nancy Stafford who has already done Oscar and Emmy type work in the past and there definitely needs to be equal awards in recognition for this kind of work.  The writing was crisp, photography beautifully done and everything about it spells a Christmas Classic.  I have been a film and TV buff for over 70 years, have even used both as a classroom teacher and feel confident that Christmas Oranges will become a Holiday tradition.  I won't be a spoiler about the plot, a lot of information is out already.  I will just say don't waste any more time reading this, get the film.  You will have something added to your list of things to be thankful for.
summary: A Christmas Classic Deserving Ten Stars

reviewText: This is a very nice family movie. Yes, it is a very predictable movie for adults, but if you have little ones, I think this movie is quite nice. Some of the acting by the children was not great, but the little girl who played Rose did a good job. I don't think this would be a smashing hit with teenagers, but for younger ones it would be good. I would probably equate this with an American Girl movie…but I must say that the actors in those movies are clearly more experienced….so there it is.

reviewerName: Penny Zeller, Christian Author and Speaker
reviewText: As a movie reviewer on a quest to find wholesome family entertainment, I’m always thrilled to find a heartwarming movie that I hadn’t heard much about and discover a gem in the process.Such is the case with Christmas Oranges.Rose was abandoned as a baby on the steps of Greenwoods Orphanage. The motherly caretaker, widow Mrs. Hartley, takes Rose in to the orphanage and raises her, along with the other children of the orphanage, as if they were her own. The children enjoy a loving environment and all is well until the unspeakable happens.Rose is then transferred to Irongates Orphanage, a place opposite in every way from the Greenwoods Orphanage. Under cruel Mr. Crampton’s direction, the children at Irongates are under strict rule with no love and very little attention.Rose is immediately grateful for the new friends she finds at Irongates, as well as, Mr. Crampton’s kind brother Joe, and Polly, the cook. She hears of the stories of what happens on Christmas – the only day Mr. Crampton allows the children to have any fun. It’s on that special day that Joe brings each child an orange – oranges he has hung on the Christmas tree on Christmas Eve. Rose finds it difficult to wait for Christmas Day.Along the way, Rose encounters difficulties at every turn with Mr. Crampton. When she discovers he harbors a secret, will her gentle spirit sway him to realize the mistakes he’s made and that it’s never too late to start anew?Christmas Oranges has quickly become one of my favorite films. Delightful, heartwarming, and humorous in parts, I was thrilled to have stumbled upon it. Christmas Oranges is not a Christian film, but it does have some wonderful lessons for discussion. For example: love despite biological ties, loyalty, friendship, forgiveness, grace, and serving others. There is nothing objectionable in this movie.But I will give you one word of caution: you may need a Kleenex. I know I did.I highly recommended this movie for all ages for Christmas and for any time of the year.This review first appeared on my Mom-Approved Movie Listing on my wordpress blog.
summary: highly recommended for Christmas and any time of the year.
